facts.fact: Magic: The Gathering was created by mathematician Richard Garfield and introduced by Wizards of the Coast in 1993.
The first Magic: The Gathering set, called Alpha, had a limited print run of 2.6 million cards.
The rarest Magic card, the Black Lotus from Alpha, can sell for tens of thousands of dollars.
The game's popularity led to the creation of the Pro Tour in 1996, providing professional competition for players.
The Reserved List, created in 1996, contains cards that Wizards of the Coast has promised never to reprint.
In 2008, a player won a match in a Magic tournament in one turn, using a deck called 'Crimson Kobolds.'
Mark Rosewater, head designer of Magic, has a background in TV sitcoms and once worked on 'Roseanne.'
Magic: The Gathering has over 20,000 unique cards, with new sets released regularly.
The longest Magic card name is 'The Nameless One,' from the Unhinged set.
The largest creature printed in the game is Emrakul, the Aeons Torn, a 15/15 creature.
In 2019, a rare Black Lotus card sold for over $166,000, setting a new record for the game.
Magic: The Gathering has been translated into 11 languages, including Japanese, German, and Chinese.
The card 'Shahrazad' was banned in several formats for its ability to create subgames within a game.
In 2003, a Magic card tournament with a prize of $250,000 was held in Houston, Texas.
Magic: The Gathering has inspired novels, comics, and even an animated series called 'Magic: The Gathering - The Animated Series.'
The card 'Chaos Orb' has a unique ability: you can drop it from a height to destroy cards on the playing field.
There are over 15,000 unique Magic: The Gathering cards currently legal in the Legacy format.
In 1999, a special set called 'Portal Three Kingdoms' was released, based on the historical Chinese novel 'Romance of the Three Kingdoms.'
The artist with the most Magic card illustrations is Rebecca Guay, known for her ethereal and dreamlike style.
The card 'Lightning Bolt' is considered one of the most iconic and powerful spells in the game.
Magic: The Gathering has a comprehensive set of rules, totaling over 200 pages.
The card 'Timetwister' is part of the Power Nine, a set of cards considered the most powerful in the game.
In 2020, Magic: The Gathering celebrated its 27th anniversary with numerous special events and releases.
The most expensive Magic: The Gathering card ever sold is a Black Lotus from the Alpha set, which went for over $500,000 in 2021.
The card 'Tarmogoyf' has fluctuated greatly in price over the years, reaching highs of over $200.
Magic: The Gathering has an organized play system that includes events like Grand Prix, Players Tour, and the Magic World Championship.
The card 'Ancestral Recall' is part of the Power Nine and is considered one of the most powerful draw spells in the game.
In 2015, Magic: The Gathering was inducted into the National Toy Hall of Fame in recognition of its cultural impact.
The term 'planeswalker' in Magic lore refers to powerful beings who can travel between different planes of existence.
In 2018, Magic: The Gathering Arena, a digital version of the game, was released, allowing players to compete online.
The card 'Black Lotus' is often cited as the most iconic and powerful card in Magic: The Gathering.
